metadata.title: Respiratory Infections Increase the Risk of Granulation Tissue Formation Following Airway Stenting in Patients With Malignant Airway Obstruction

sections.abstract: Background: The most serious complications of airway stenting are long term, including infection and granulation tissue formation. However, no studies had quantified the incidence rate of long-term complications for different stents. Methods: Retrospective cohort of all patients at a single cancer center receiving airway stents for malignant airway obstruction (January 2005-August 2010). Patients with >1 stent type in place simultaneously were excluded. Complications recorded: lower respiratory tract infections, migration, granulation tissue, mucus plugging requiring intervention, tumor overgrowth, fracture. Results: 172 patients with 195 stent procedures were included (Ultraflex 118, Aero 31, Dumon silicone 46). Aero stents increased infection risk (HR 1.98; 95% CI 1.03-3.81; p=0.041). Dumon silicone tube stents increased migration risk (HR 3.52; 95% CI 1.41-8.82; p=0.007). Silicone stents (HR 3.32; 95% CI 1.59-6.93; p=0.001) and lower respiratory tract infections (HR 5.69; 95% CI 2.60-12.42; p<0.001) increased risk of granulation tissue. Lower respiratory tract infections were associated with decreased survival (HR 1.57; 95% CI 1.11-2.21; p=0.011). Conclusions: Stent type is associated with different risks of infection, migration, and granulation tissue; infections confer substantial morbidity and mortality and are strongly linked to granulation tissue formation.
sections.methods: Design: Retrospective cohort at The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center. Population: All patients undergoing airway stenting for malignant central airway obstruction from January 2005 to August 2010. Exclusions: concurrent use of >1 stent type. Data abstraction: standardized forms with predefined definitions in a codebook; radiologist blinded to clinical data reviewed CTs. Interventions: Expandable metal stents placed with flexible/rigid bronchoscopy; silicone stents placed with rigid bronchoscopy; no perioperative or prophylactic antibiotics/steroids. Outcomes: Primary—time to lower respiratory tract infection (clinical diagnosis requiring antibiotics; pneumonia vs acute bronchitis classification per imaging). Secondary—time to migration, granulation tissue, mucus plugging requiring bronchoscopic cleaning, tumor overgrowth, stent fracture (all bronchoscopically confirmed except infections). Statistical analysis: Time-to-event measured from implantation to event; censoring at last follow-up. Univariate Cox models; time-varying covariates (e.g., infection) coded 0 until event then 1. Variables with p<0.10 entered multivariable extended Cox models with backward elimination (retain p<0.05). Kaplan-Meier plots. Two-sided p<0.05 significant. Software: SAS 9.1 and S-Plus 7.0.
sections.results: Stents: Ultraflex 118/195 (60%), Aero 31/195 (16%), Dumon silicone 46/195 (24%; 28 Y, 18 tube). Events among 195 procedures: lower respiratory tract infection in 73 (106 total infection episodes); granulation tissue 38; mucus impaction 48; hemoptysis 17; migration 27 (among 167 procedures after excluding 28 Y stents); fracture 4; new fistula 2; tumor overgrowth 25. Infections: median time 1 month (0-35); 45% outpatient, 34% admitted to floor, 21% ICU; 13% required mechanical ventilation; 11% required stent removal; 23% died within 14 days of infection. Multivariable: Aero vs Ultraflex increased infection risk (HR 1.98; 95% CI 1.03-3.81; p=0.041). Migration: silicone tube stents vs Ultraflex HR 3.52 (95% CI 1.41-8.82; p=0.007). Granulation: silicone stents HR 3.32 (95% CI 1.59-6.93; p=0.001) and time-varying infection HR 5.69 (95% CI 2.60-12.42; p<0.001). Mucus impaction: left-sided location increased risk; older age and post-stent chemotherapy decreased risk. Survival (172 patients; median follow-up 3 months): lower respiratory tract infection increased mortality HR 1.57 (95% CI 1.11-2.21; p=0.011); silicone and tracheal stents associated with lower mortality; pre-stent radiation associated with higher mortality.

population.text: Adults with malignant central airway obstruction undergoing therapeutic airway stenting at a tertiary cancer center.
inclusion_criteria: Airway stenting performed for malignant airway obstruction
Stent placed between January 2005 and August 2010
Single stent type in place at any one time
exclusion_criteria: More than one stent type in place concurrently
Stent models with too few cases for analysis (e.g., Montgomery T-tube, Polyflex)

intervention.details: Placed via flexible or rigid bronchoscopy; no prophylactic antibiotics or steroids.

comparison.details: Placed via flexible or rigid bronchoscopy; served as reference in Cox models.

outcomes.name: Time to lower respiratory tract infection
Time to mucus plugging requiring intervention

outcomes_normalized.name: Time to lower respiratory tract infection

analysis.population: All stent procedures (n=195); multivariable extended Cox with backward elimination

provenance.quote: Aero stents (hazard ratio [HR] 5 1.98; 95% CI, 1.03-3.81; P5 .041) had a significant effect on infection risk.

outcomes_normalized.name: Effect of lower respiratory tract infection on time to granulation tissue

provenance.quote: Lower respiratory tract infection (HR 5 5.69; 95% CI, 2.60-12.42; P , .001) was associated with increased risk for granulation.

outcomes_normalized.name: Time to stent migration (silicone tube vs Ultraflex)

provenance.quote: Silicone tube stents (HR 5 3.52; 95% CI, 1.41-8.82; P5 .007) had a significant effect on migration risk.

outcomes_normalized.name: Any lower respiratory tract infection (patients with ≥1 episode)

provenance.quote: Lower respiratory tract infection (time varying): Yes 73 (37.44%) among 195 procedures.

safety_normalized.management: Antibiotics in all; bronchoscopy as needed; ICU admission in 22/106; mechanical ventilation in 14/106; stent removal in 12/106.

provenance.quote: Seventy-three patients had 106 lower respiratory tract infections... Admitted to hospital floor 36 (34%), ICU 22 (21%); Mechanical ventilation 14 (13%); Stent removal required 12 (11%); Death within 14 d of infection 24 (23%).

domains.name: Confounding
domains.support_for_judgment: Non-randomized retrospective cohort with potential residual confounding; multivariable Cox models used but unmeasured confounding likely.

domains.name: Selection of participants
domains.support_for_judgment: Consecutive cases at a single center; exclusions when multiple stent types present.

domains.name: Classification of interventions
domains.support_for_judgment: Stent type clearly identified from procedural records.

domains.name: Deviations from intended interventions
domains.support_for_judgment: Usual care; no prophylactic antibiotics or steroids administered per protocol.

domains.name: Missing data
domains.support_for_judgment: Censoring at last follow-up; short median follow-up (3 months) could affect event capture.

domains.name: Measurement of outcomes
domains.support_for_judgment: Bronchoscopic confirmation for most structural outcomes; infections defined by clinical criteria and treatment.

domains.name: Selection of the reported result
domains.support_for_judgment: Pre-specified outcomes with comprehensive reporting of hazard ratios and incidence.

retrieval.summary_tldr: In a single-center cohort (195 stent procedures), Aero stents doubled infection risk vs Ultraflex (HR 1.98), silicone stents tripled migration risk and granulation risk; infections markedly increased granulation risk (HR 5.69) and mortality (HR 1.57).
retrieval.clinical_relevance: Stent selection influences long-term complications; preventing and promptly treating respiratory infections may reduce granulation and improve outcomes after airway stenting for malignant obstruction.
